Some sources report that the abductee was a presumed cleric, the police claimed that the abductee who was not a catholic priest or cleric was released and he was able to reclaim his car from the police station, there are no reports on ransom payment.
On 24 April 2023, Nigerian troops who were on a patrol set off an IED that was planted by ISWAP militants at Layi village (Mobbar, Borno). All Five soldiers who were onboard the vehicle were killed.

On 24 April 2023, an IED presumed to have been planted by ISWAP detonated on a patrol of Nigerian soldiers at San San village, 1km away from Damasak (Mobbar, Borno). One soldier was killed and an unspecifed number of others were wounded.
On 24 April 2023, ISWAP militants fired in Goniri town (Gujba, Yobe) and the the bombs drooped far from the military camp and civilian population with any impact.

On 24 April 2023, an unidentified armed group killed a man whom they had chased along Illabouchi street in Mile 2, Diobu (Port Harcourt, Rivers). The assailants zoomed off after shooting the victim, some residents claimed that the attack was linked to the tussle between two factions of Deebam cult militia, the police claimed that the victim fell on a pavement while being chased and sustained injuries for whuch he was confirmed dead at a hospital.

On 24 April 2023, residents Ajiran community (Eti-Osa, Lagos) coded to Ajiran Osapa Ward protested over the lack of motorable roads and other amenities in the area. The protesters demanded for the state government's intervention and that of the police to prevent a breakdown of law and order.

On 24 April 2023, suspected IS Sahel militants killed the president school management committees (COGES) of the Begorou Tondo General Education College (CEG) in the village of Handaga (Tera, Tillaberi).

On 23 April 2023, suspected armed pastoralists numbering four killed a farmer and wounded 8 other persons at Ago-Oyinbo in Ala Forest Reserve (Idanre, Ondo). The assailants who were heavily armed also looted victims' property, other persons fled their homes due to fear of being attacked. Other sources report that the attack was over the community's refusal the assailants' cattle graze in the area.

On 23 April 2023, a suspected Hausa-Fulani militia attacked traders at the yam section of Artisan market in Enugu (Enugu North, Enugu). An unspecified number of persons were wounded by the assailants who weilded daggers and machetes, hundreds of yam tubers were stolen.

On 23 April 2023, Gbagyi and Hausa ethnic militias clashed in Gwarinpa (Abuja Municipal, FCT). The clash was temporarily brought under control and continued the following morning [coded separately]; three persons were killed, several others were wounded and cars were vandalized. Some sources report that the clash resulted from an attempt by the Gbagyi militia to retaliate the robbery of a local politician by a group of Hausa persons. 3 fatalities split across 2 events coded as 2.

On 23 April 2023, ISWAP militants abducted four residents of Layi village (Mobbar, Borno) including the local chief and planted landmines while retreating. The mines exploded the following day when troops on patrol stepped on it [coded separately].

source: Daily Independent (Nigeria); Daily Trust (Nigeria); Nigeria Punch
notes: On 23 April 2023, an unidentified armed group abducted a woman at Ogbokiri junction (Emohua, Rivers). The abductee was the federal commissioner representing Bayelsa at the National Population Commission, she was abducted alongside her driver and maid while they were traveling to Port Harcourt from Bayelsa, a ransom of 500 million naira was demanded. They were released on 28 April, there are no reports about ransom payment.

On 23 April 2023, a private security guard killed a civilian at Alagbaka area (Akure North, Ondo) after he was accosted and interrogated over his movement in the area. The assailant and his colleagues fled the area.

On 23 April 2023, an unidentified armed group attacked and killed four people in Heipang (Barkin Ladi, Plateau). The assailants also destroyed residents' properties and wounded many others. Other sources report the attack was the result of a clash between two communities.
On 23 April 2023, an unidentified armed group attacked and killed one person in Kwi (Riyom, Plateau).

On 23 April 2023, policemen intercepted an unidentified armed group and engaged them in an armed clash along Ndofia Ishieke and Edupfu Egbu Ishieke (Ebonyi, Ebonyi) coded to Ugbodo. The armed group had abducted a cleric who was rescued by the policemen, one member of the group was killed, two others were arrested, two rifles and two vehicles were recovered.
On 23 April 2023, an unidentified armed group attacked and killed two people in Unguwar Wereng (Riyom, Plateau).
On 23 April 2023, an unidentified armed group riding on motorcycles killed two people in Kuru (Jos South, Plateau). The first vitim was shot and killed, the second corpse was found the following day.

On 23 April 2023, ISWAP militants launched RPGs and mortar bombs into a camp of Nigerian troops at Waijroko (Damboa, Borno). The troops responded with firepower and the militants fled and avoided making contact with them. There were no casualties.

On 23 April 2023, members of rival unidentified cult militias engaged in an armed clash in Abayomi and Gambari areas of Ilorin (Ilorin West, Kwara). One person was killed, his corpse was dragged to the front of a mosque where it was abandoned after his left eye and left hand were removed.

Looting: On 23 April 2023, a suspected unidentified cult militia robbed residents and looted shops on different streets in Mile 1 Diobu (Port Harcourt, Rivers). The militiamen had set up roadblocks and operated for over 40 minutes.

On 23 April 2023, kinsmen of a victim who was murdered by a private security guard [coded separately] destroyed the house of the chairman of the area in Alagbaka (Akure North, Ondo) while demonstrating over the victim's death. The assailants were said to have reported the incident to the chairman before fleeing, the demonstrators demanded for the arrest of the assailants.

On 22 April 2023, youth stormed the chief's palace in Kukurantumi (East Akim, Eastern) to disrupt the installation of a new Queen mother that was planned to take place later in the day. Police intervened and were able to calm the situation. The new queen mother is suspected of being the niece of the chief.
On 22 April 2023, FAMa soldiers killed 12 civilians, all women and children in the village of Tarbakaro (Nara, Koulikoro).
On 22 April 2023, Dan Na Ambassagou militiamen killed two Fulani men by beheading in the village of Doundou (Mopti, Mopti).

Eight soldiers were wounded including two severely with limbs amputated according to an initial toll. JNIM claimed responsibility and said it killed 10 soldiers, acknowledged 3 killed in its ranks, and displayed a vehicle, several weapons, ammunition, and equipment captured. 13 fatalities coded.

assoc_actor_2: Wagner Group; MINUSMA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in Mali (2021-)
source: AFP; Al Zallaqa; AP; FAMAMali; Koro Kibaru; Ministry of Territorial Administration and Decentralization - Mali; Sahelien; Studio Tamani; Twitter; Undisclosed Source; Whatsapp; Xinhua
notes: On 22 April 2023, JNIM militants executed a complex attack involving three suicide car bombs (SVBIEDs), targeting FAMa and Wagner positions at the airport in the town of Sevare (Mopti, Mopti). Malian TB2 Bayraktar drones carried out airstrikes, which led to the premature detonation of two SVBIEDs. The explosions caused extensive damage to the IDP site, a gas station, and 20 buildings destroyed and many civilians houses that collapsed, many with occupants inside. Senegalese peacekeepers repelled attackers who had encircled the airport. 28 militants and 10 civilians were killed, and 61 civilians were wounded, according to a government statement. Local sources indicated that five FAMa soldiers were killed and some described as militants killed were IDPs including children, while the head of Wagner denied any losses in Wagner ranks. JNIM claimed responsibility and acknowledged 15 killed in its ranks including suicide bombers and members of the assault squad. 43 fatalities coded.

Seven militiamen were killed, their camps were destroyed, seven motorcycles and other items were recovered. 7 fatalities split across 3 events coded as 3.

On 22 April 2023, troops of Operation Hadarin Daji engaged a Zamfara militia in an armed clash at Dumburum forest (Zurmi, Zamfara) and other locations [coded separately]. Seven militiamen were killed, their camps were destroyed, seven motorcycles and other items were recovered. 7 fatalities split across 3 events coded as 2.

Seven militiamen were killed, their camps were destroyed, seven motorcycles and other items were recovered. 7 fatalities split across 3 events coded as 2.

On 22 April 2023, rioters clashed in Minna (Minna, Niger) following an Eid celebration that turned violent. One person was killed, several others were wounded and 37 persons were arrested by the police.
On 21 April 2023, students held a protest sit-in at the university of Nouakchott (Tevragh-Zeina, Nouakchott) to denounce the closure of the university restaurant during the Aid holidays.

On 21 April 2023, an unidentified armed group attacked people celebrating Eid-Al-Fitr in Sakpere, coded to Bawku (Bawku, Upper East). 6 were killed, 4 died on the spot while 2 others died at the hospital.

source: CKN Nigeria; Daily Independent (Nigeria); Nigerian Eye; Sun (Nigeria)
notes: On 21 April 2023, suspected IPOB militants attacked policemen at Okpala junction (Ngor Okpala, Imo) coded to Umuneke Ngor when they went to eat. 4 to 5 policemen and a civilian couple in whose shop two of the policemen had tried to hide were killed, the policemen's rifles were taken away. Other sources report that the attack was carried out as a reprisal for the raid of an IPOB hideout and the killing of an unspecified number of militants by the police the previous day. IPOB denied involvement in the clash and claimed that the pepertrators were paid criminals.

On 21 April 2023, suspected armed pastoralists ambushed and killed four mourners at Ankpali (Apa, Benue). The chairman of the Benue state ward chapter of LP was one of the murdered victims, many others were wounded and several others were missing.

On 21 April 2023, ISWAP claimed to have killed 8 members of an unidentified communal militia near Gauni village in Borno state, location coded to Maiduguri (Maiduguri Metro, Borno). Other sources report that militias from the North West region had infiltrated Borno and Yobe states seeking safe haven.

On 21 April 2023, students of Adeyemi college of education in their numbers protested on the Akure-Ore highway, coded to Ore (Odigbo, Ondo) over the campus' lack of electricity and water in the last few months. The protesters also carried empty buckets to show their grievance.

On 21 April 2023, a Niger militia from the camp of Dogo Jede engaged another Niger militia from Ali Kachalla's camp in an armed clash at Kusasu village in Shiroro LGA (Niger). Dogo Jede's camp launched the attack in an attempt to retrieve cattle that Ali Kachalla's camp stole from them. The clash lasted for several hours; 6 Kachalla loyalists and two of Jede's were killed, over 5000 cattle was recovered and scores of other militiamen were injured. Other sources report that the fatalities is expected to increase due to the degrees of injuries sustained.

On 21 April 2023, an unidentified cult militia killed two suspected members of an unidentified cult militia whom they had trailed from Lagos to Ilorin (Ilorin West, Kwara). The victims were killed while they were returning from the mosque, one of them tried to pull out his gun when he was shot, macheted and his head was severed.

notes: On 6 April 2023, Wagner mercenaries carried out an operation in the area of Sagala (Segou, Segou). About ten people (the majority from the Fulani and Tuareg Bellah community) were killed and others went missing. The bodies of those killed were discovered in the surrounding bush. In addition to the killings, the mercenaries also set fire to a large part of the bushland.

Looting: On 6 April 2023, Dan Na Ambassagou militiamen seized two herds of livestock in the area of Koloni (Mopti, Mopti). The seizure came in reprisal for an earlier incursion by JNIM militants in the village of Kouna.

actor1: JNIM: Group for Support of Islam and Muslims
notes: Looting: On 6 April 2023, JNIM militants attacked the village of Kouna (Mopti, Mopti). The militants seized more than 500 heads of livestock.

On 6 April 2023, a number of artisanal miners with machettes and clubs assaulted and wounded a farmer in the village of Djilenfing (Yanfolila, Sikasso). The artisanal miners who are from the same village as the farmer wanted the extract gold on his plantation.

On 6 April 2023, IS Sahel fighters captured several suspected robbers in Fafa (Ansongo, Gao). Those captured are believed to have pretended being IS Sahel members when robbing passengers aboard transport vehicles in the area Firthindi along the Ansongo and Labbezanga road on 5 April.

On 6 April 2023, PDP members abducted the state legal adviser of the APC at the headquarters of INEC in Port Harcourt (Port Harcourt, Rivers) after he received some election documents from INEC. The abductee was released the following day, there are no details on ransom payment.

On 6 April 2023, Kutep and Fulani militias clashed at Kwesati and Fikye (Ussa, Taraba) after the Kutep militia attacked pastoralists as reprisal over an attack by a suspected Fulani militia [coded separately]. Many persons were killed and many residential buildings were set ablaze including the house of the paramount ruler of Lisam Kwe who was accused by youths of taking sides with the Fulanis. Unknown fatalities coded as 10.

On 6 April 2023, policemen clashed with an unidentified armed group when they raided the group's hideout in Ikorodu (Ikorodu, Lagos). One member of the group was killed and two abductees were rescued.

actor1: Boko Haram - Jamaatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawati wal-Jihad
notes: On 6 April 2023, Boko Haram militants [JAS faction] killed a pastor and wounded his wife when they invaded Madthaw village coded to Miringa (Biu, Borno) which is 9km away. Some other persons were wounded, buildings were destroyed, foodstuff and livestock were looted by the militants.

Around 6 April 2023 (as reported), a Sokoto militia killed an abductee they abducted from his hometown in Rabah LGA (Sokoto) a few weeks earlier. The victim's family paid a ransom of 2 million naira for his release.

assoc_actor_2: Former Police Forces of Nigeria (2015-) Nigeria Immigration Service
notes: On 6 April 2023, an unidentified armed group killed a retired immigration officer whom they abducted around Ombi II in Lafia (Lafia, Nassarawa) where they mounted a roadblock. The victim's body was found in the area the following morning.

On 6 April 2023, a suspected unidentified cult militia dressed in black clothes trailed and killed a motorist at Irona area of Ado-Ekiti (Ado Ekiti, Ekiti). The victim was shot and his body was macheted by the assailants who took a bag from his car and fled.

Property destruction: On 6 April 2023, policemen and a group suspected to be affiliated with the APC vandalized properties at the LP secretariat in Utako (Abuja Municipal, FCT). The assailants pulled down fences, doors, windows and burglaries which prompted staff to flee, the LP chairman claimed that they were working for the APC.

On 6 April 2023, a mob of four killed a man in Dallaji (Warji, Bauchi) after he was accused of stealing watermelons worth 2000 naira from a farm. The victim was evacuated by policemen and taken to the hospital where he died, four persons were arrested in connection with the attack.
On 6 April 2023, hundreds of PDP members protested at the INEC office in Port Harcourt (Port Harcourt, Rivers) for the fourth day to demand for the joint inspection of the 2023 election materials.

On 6 April 2023, students of Adekunle Ajasin University who were demonstrating in Akunba (Akoko South West, Ondo) set fire to the house of the mother of man who was suspected to have stabbed their colleague to death. The demonstrators were dispersed by policemen who put out the fire and prevented them from demonstrating further.

On 6 April 2023, an unidentified armed group attacked the sub-chief of village in his 50's in Karaga (Karaga, Northern). The sub-chief died at the hospital. The attack is believed to be connected to the Karaga chieftaincy dispute.

Around 6 April 2023, residents of Nsuta-Atonsu who are mostly farmers protested around Nsuta (Sekyere Central, Ashanti) against what they call the Fulani herdsmen invasion. The protesters say that the cattle are destroying food crops and competing with residents for drinking water.
On 6 April 2023, an unidentified armed group abducted three girls as they were returning from school in Ikeja (Ikeja, Lagos). The reason for the attack is unknown and there are no ransom demands.

On 6 April 2023, an unidentified armed group wounded one person and abducted 14 persons from Chida community in Kwali Area Council (FCT). The wounded victim was shot when he attempted to flee, the community's traditional chief was one of the abductees. There are no reports about ransom demands.
Looting: On 6 April 2023, overnight presumed IS Sahel militants seized livestock in the village of Iskita (Abala, Tillaberi).

On 5 April 2023, a policeman shot and killed a civilian along Ugbolu-Illah road (Oshimili North, Delta) following a disagreement over bribe payment when the victim was stopped at a checkpoint for a search. The police claimed that the assailant policeman was arrested.

On 5 April 2023, a mob of commercial motorcyclists clashed with policemen at Cele Bus Stop along Apapa-Oshodi expressway (Oshodi, Lagos). One policeman was killed, three guns belonging to policemen were also claimed to have been hijacked, the reason for the clash is unknown. The police claimed that they arrested two person in connection with the clash and impounded 41 motorcycles.

On 5 April 2023, traders at UTC market in Abuja (Abuja Municipal, FCT) protested against the demolition of the market's perimeter fence. The protesters claimed that the demolition was contrary to a court order which mandated all parties to maintain status quo.
On 5 April 2023, youths protested in Asaba (Oshimili South, Delta) against the murder of a civilian by policemen at a checkpoint. The protesters marched through the streets in search of policemen.

On 5 April 2023, two unidentified armed men aboard a pickup truck intercepted another vehicle between Arlit (Arlit, Agadez) and Tabarkat [Tchibarakaten] (Iferouane, Agadez). The assailants robbed cash and the vehicle from the two occupants.

Looting: On 3 April 2023, IS Sahel militants seized a herd of livestock in Echagh (Gao, Gao).

Around 3 April 2023 (as reported), ISWAP claimed to have detonated an explosive device on a patrol of the Nigerian Army near Doshi village which led to burning of an armored vehicle, damage to another vehicle and four soldiers that were killed and wounded. Other sources claim that the location does not exist in Borno, and sources in Dokshi (Gulami, Yobe) claim that there were no attacks in the area.

On 3 April 2023, hunters and an unidentified communal militia clashed at the Sabon Gari-Trikaniya area (Chikun, Kaduna). The clash started the previous day [coded separately], two people were killed and six others were wounded, 2 fatalities split across two events coded as 1. The state government imposed a curfew in the area to curtail further attacks.

On 3 April 2023, a local defense militia numbering over 60 killed one person and wounded several others at Dugwer community in Bali LGA (Taraba) while trying to eject them from a land. The assailants also looted farm products, motorcycles and personal belongings. Residents claimed that the state governor had indicted interest to take over the land and the assailants were working on the orders of the Chief of Jibu.
On 3 April 2023, suspected armed pastoralists in their numbers attacked civilians in Kwesati (Ussa, Taraba). At least 10 people were killed and houses were set ablaze by the assailants.

On 3 April 2023, a policeman shot and killed two civilians in Jos (Jos North, Plateau). The victims were a trader and a commercial tricycle rider, other sources report that the second victim was an okada rider who was wounded and that the trader was hit by a stray bullet as a result of sporadic shooting by policemen who invaded the market and attempted to arrest commercial okada riders.

On 3 April 2023, an unidentified armed group attacked and killed three persons in Igbobi community (Apa, Benue) coded to Ugbokpo. The traditional ruler of the community was one of the victims, he was abducted and later killed.

On 3 April 2023, a suspected unidentified cult militia shot and killed a student of University of Benin in his hostel in Benin City (Oredo, Edo). Other sources report that the victim was the school's chief of Kegite, students chased away security operatives who arrived the scene after and also chased away other students who were in class.

On 3 April 2023, an unidentified cult militia killed a staunch Islamic faithful along the Atundaolu area of Ado-Ekiti (Ado Ekiti, Ekiti). The victim was hit in the head with a stick after the assailants noticed that the bullets shot at him did not have any effect. The reason for the attack is unknown.

Other sources report that the APC candidate's was attacked on his way to the INEC office and that his security detail was also attacked by the assailants who were an unidentified armed group.

On 3 April 2023, members of the PDP in Rivers state led by the deputy speaker of the state house of assembly protested at the INEC headquarters in Port Harcourt (Port Harcourt, Rivers) to demand for a joint inspection of election materials by political parties ahead of the election petition tribunal sitting in the state.

Demonstrators threw stones and law enforcement fired tear gas. 5 police officers were injured and 3 demonstrators were arrested.

On 9 March 2023, former Niger-Delta agitators protested at Uvwiamuge junction (Ughelli North, Delta) over claims that a pipeline surveillance project belonging to the Urhobo ethnic group was hijacked by the senator representing the district.

On 9 March 2023, an unidentified armed group suspected to be APC supporters shot and killed a presumed OPC member and two other persons at Akere spare parts market in Ajegunle (Ajeromi, Lagos). The assailants also set the market ablaze and destroyed properties worth millions of naira, the attack is suspected to have been politically motivated against Igbo traders due to their assumed preference for the LP gubernatorial candidate.

On 9 March 2023, police arrested Senegal's former prime minister (Cheikh Haguibou Soumare) after he publicly suggested that the country's president had funded a French politician during a recent visit in Dakar (Plateau, Dakar). On 10 March 2023, Cheikh Haguibou Soumare was released but placed under judicial supervision.

The militants snuck in from two directions, at least one policeman was killed in the clash which lasted for about 30 and one police vehicle was taken away by the militants. Other sources report that seven villagers were abducted by the militants.
On 9 March 2023, a mob vandalized a bank and destroyed property in Oke Dio area of Saki (Saki West, Oyo). A policeman wounded one bank customer while he was trying to control the mob.
On 9 March 2023, a Katsina militia killed one person and abducted an unspecified number of others when they attacked a commuter bus that was heading to Batsari market (Batsari, Katsina).

On 9 March 2023, an unidentified armed group of locals killed a Fulani pastoralist at Unguwan Juju (Zangon Kataf, Kaduna). The victim was tied to a tree and cut to death with a machete, the attack led to reprisals in the area (coded separately).

source: Daily Independent (Nigeria); Daily Trust (Nigeria); Inside Arewa (Nigeria); Sun (Nigeria)
notes: On 8 March 2023, APC and PDP supporters clashed during a campaign rally of the APC at Duguri town (Alkaleri , Bauchi) coded to Buren Duguri. One person was shot and killed, 14 to 15 others sustained machete wounds, The PDP claimed that several others sustained varying degrees of injuries including bystanders, their billboards were destroyed, their offices and tricycles were set ablaze. Both parties accused the other for being responsible for the attack.

On 8 March 2023, suspected armed Fulani pastoralists attacked and killed 8 persons in Tse-Jor (Gwer West, Benue) coded to Naka. The victims were at the burial of victims of a previous attack, several persons sustained varying degrees of injuries, the assailants who invaded the area from Nassarawa state also set the village ablaze and fled before soldiers arrived.

source: Daily Leadership (Nigeria); Daily Trust (Nigeria); Guardian (Nigeria); HumAngle; Nigeria Punch; The Cable (Nigeria); Twitter
notes: On 8 March 2023, ISWAP militants attacked IDPs who were fishing and shot sporadically at them in Mukdolo village (Ngala, Borno) coded to Gamboru. Between 26 to 35 persons were killed, nine others escaped, three among them sustained bullet wounds. Some sources report that the militants had severally warned the victims to stay away from their zone, other sources report that the victims were also tortured by the militants. The police claimed that 29 persons were killed and nine were seriously wounded.

On 8 March 2023, policemen engaged a Katsina militia in an armed clash and repelled the militia's attack on Jabiri area of Funtua LGA (Katsina). One militiaman was killed, another was arrested and one rifle was recovered.

On 8 March 2023, troops of 13 Brigade Nigerian Army who were deployed to Operation Akpakwu ambushed an unidentified armed group at their hideout and engaged them in an armed clash around Peter Effiong Creek. The troops rescued the Cross River state commissioner for women affairs who was abducted by the group at Mayne Avenue [coded separately], while the members of the group fled. Location coded to Anantigha (Calabar South, Cross River) where the abduction was coded to.

On 8 March 2023, a Niger militia abducted a businesswoman and two of her daughters from their home in Beji town (Bosso, Niger). To other tenants of the woman were abducted but later escaped, the assailants shot sporadically in the town to scare residents away. Sources claim that the abduction was connected to the woman's refusal to allow a petrol station to serve as a fuel dump to the militiamen.

On 8 March 2023, soldiers engaged a Niger militia in an armed clash and repelled an attack on civilians in Wushishi LGA (Niger) and Rafi LGA [coded separately]. The militiamen shot sporadically at the civilians; killed 5 persons including a pregnant woman, wounded others before the soldiers arrived and fled with more than 50 people whom they abducted. Other sources report that NAF fighter jets engaged the militiamen who also attacked Rafi LGA, fatalities split across two events coded as 2.

source: Daily Trust (Nigeria); Inside Arewa (Nigeria); Nigeria Punch; Vanguard (Nigeria)

Other sources report that NAF fighter jets engaged the militiamen who also attacked Wushishi LGA, fatalities split across two events coded as 3.

On 8 March 2023, traders whose shops are located on the premises of the Lagos state vehicle inspection center at Ojodu (Ikeja, Lagos) protested over the closure of their shops by officials. On 8 March 2023, an unidentified armed group attacked Togolese soldiers in Djoatou (Kpendjal, Savanes). A dozen militants were killed, coded as 10, a dozen captured and 3 Togolese soldiers injured.

They denounce the behavior of law enforcement on the day of the Pastef leader (Ousmane Sonko) trial. He had been summoned to court to respond to the defamation charges of the Minister of Tourism.

On 17 February 2023, retirees demonstrated against the delay in the payment of their pensions in Pikine (Pikine Dagoudane, Pikine, Dakar). They blocked the road despite attempts to dissuade the police commissioner.

On 17 February 2023, a suspected Fulani militia killed two people and injured many others when they attacked Awgu Egbeleli (Agwu, Enugu) coded to Awgu. The assailants burnt motorcycles, and bicycles, harvested farmers crops and warned them not to go to their farms again. Fatalities split across two events coded as 1.

On 17 February 2023, presumed IS Sahel militants attacked the relief unit of the Deou military detachment in Tin-Ediar (Oursi, Oudalan). 51 soldiers were killed, others wounded, gone missing, and sixty militants killed in a counteroffensive, and about a hundred more in subsequent airstrikes (information that could not be independently verified), according to a government statement. IS Sahel claimed responsibility and said it killed 70 soldiers and displayed 54 corpses of soldiers killed, 5 taken prisoners, an armored vehicle burned, and a vehicle, a large amount of weapons, and ammunition captured. 130 fatalities coded.
On 17 February 2023, ISWAP claimed to have killed a soldier in a Nigerian army convoy near Gamboru (Ngala, Borno).
On 17 February 2023, rioters demonstrated and vandalized commercial banks in Oron (Oron, Akwa Ibom) over the nationwide scarcity of naira notes.

On 16 February 2023, presumed IS Sahel militants killed a civilian and stole livestock in the town of Markoye (Markoye, Oudalan).

On 16 February 2023, FAMa killed two persons and arrested several others including a muezzin at the market in Boni (Douentza, Mopti).
On 16 February 2023, a mob threw stones and destroyed a bank and facilities within it at Rumuokoro (Obio, Rivers) while demonstrating over naira notes scarcity.

On 16 February 2023, a policeman shot sporadically to disperse residents that tried to resist the arrest of one person at Doubeli (Yola-South, Adamawa). One female relative of the suspect was was hit by a stray bullet and killed, and one other person was wounded. The police claimed that the policeman was arrested.

On 16 February 2023, an unidentified armed group was repelled by joint security operatives (police and military forces) when they attacked a training at Ukpor (Nnewi South, Anambra) where INEC staff and ad hoc staff including NYSC members were preparing for the elections. There were no casualties, joint security patrols in the area were intensified.

notes: On 16 February 2023, residents demonstrated against the ruling military regime, at the call of the FNDC opposition group in several districts of Conakry (Kaloum, Conakry). Demonstrators gathered in neighborhoods around Le Prince axis (Hamdalaye, Cosa, Koloma, Bailobaya, Sonfonia). They erected road blocks in several locations in Conakry and threw stones at security forces, including police, gendarmerie and the army that was called in as a reinforcement. Security forces responded with tear gas and by shooting at the demonstrators. 3 of them died, around 50 people were wounded. Several journalists were threatened by the military and one journalist was robbed of his memory card.

Two militants were killed in the clash and a pastoralist man killed in an airstrike. The residents managed to flee, although the coalition burned about forty houses, granaries, and killed livestock, and also seized herds of cows and sheep. Eventual casualties in coalition ranks are unknown.

On 15 February 2023, demonstrators set a bank ablaze while demonstrating in Udu LGA (Delta) coded to Otor Udu over the scarcity of the new naira notes and hike in fuel price. Other sources report that two persons were killed, several others were wounded and three banks were burned down, the police spokesperson in the state denied the claims of fatalities.

On 15 February 2023, rioters clashed with military forces who fired gunshots in an attempt to disperse a crowd that was demonstrating in Benin City (Oredo, Edo) over their inability to spend old naira notes. Three persons were killed, the rioters set bonfires on major roads, attacked commercial banks and destroyed their ATMs. The state government claimed that the demonstration was politically motivated, the governor demanded that his predecessor should be arrested for instigating people to riot, the claims of the governor were denied by the former governor's spokesman.

On 15 February 2023, hundreds of fish sellers most of whom were women protested at premises of a radio station along Iwo road-Ojoo expressway, coded to Akinyele (Akinyele, Oyo) over the rejection of old naira notes by cold room operators.

source: Daily Leadership (Nigeria); Daily Post (Nigeria); Guardian (Nigeria); Risk and Strategic Management, Corporation
notes: On 15 February 2023, demonstrators barricaded roads with tires that they set ablaze in Ilorin (Ilorin West, Kwara) while demonstrating over the scarcity of new naira notes and the rejection of old higher bank notes by traders in Oloje and Oko-Olowo areas. Soldiers were deployed to the area and they shot sporadically to disperse the demonstrators, five of whom were arrested.

On 15 February 2023, hundreds of youths set up bonfires and demonstrated on the major streets of Oturkpo and the Enugu -Oturkpo highway (Otukpo, Benue) over naira notes and fuel scarcity. Policemen intervened and restored calm in the area.

The attack was a reprisal, for the murder of a soldier by a policeman who ran into the station [coded separately]. The military authorities claimed that the attack was carried out by a mob and not soldiers.

On 15 February 2023, demonstrators burnt tires on the roads in different parts of Ondo town (Ondo West, Ondo) while demonstrating over the scarcity of new naira notes.

On 15 February 2023, soldiers attacked and beat up a commuter who was on his way to Ikorodu (Ikorodu, Lagos) for having a police sticker on his car. The soldiers were on a reprisal over the murder of their colleague by a policeman around the area [coded separately].
On 15 February 2023, demonstrators burnt tires on the roads and vandalized billboards in Ovwian town (Udu, Delta) while demonstrating over the scarcity of new naira notes.

On 15 February 2023, protesters who were protesting in parts of Ogbomosho town (Ogbomosho North, Oyo) over their inability to withdraw money were dispersed by the police operatives.

On 15 February 2023, demonstrators marched to request the release of the singer Nit Doff and all political prisoners in Dakar (Plateau, Dakar).

On 7 February 2023, Amasiri and Nde Ndukwe attacked farm settlements in Oso (Afikpo South, Ebonyi) and killed one person during the attacks which started the previous day and lasted for 3 days before the intervention of security operatives. Houses, farm produce and properties were destroyed, four others were abducted and later released after a peace meeting organized by council chairmen and monarchs. The murdered victim was behead, his head was taken away by the assailants. Fatality split across 3 events, coded as 0.

source: Daily Post (Nigeria); Daily Trust (Nigeria); Sahara Reporters
notes: On 4 February 2023, a mob that was suspected to have been politically motivated and affiliated with an APC senator attacked the convoy of the wife of the Adamawa state governor at Muchalla in Mubi North LGA (Adamawa). The rioters threw stones, at the bus convoying the press crew, one person was wounded and the bus was damaged. Other sources report that the wounded victim was a former aide of the senator and the mob insisted that the first lady was not welcome in the area which is the home town of the senator.

Around 4 February 2023 (as reported), an unidentified armed group killed 7 members of the family of the district head of Mutum Biyu who were abducted [coded separately] from Mutum Biyu (Gassol, Taraba). 8 persons including the head's two wives and six children were abducted, one of them escaped and the rest were killed and their decomposing bodies were found.

On 4 February 2023, women and youths from Ezza clan protested around Onueke urban (Ezza South, Ebonyi) against the attempted assassination of the APGA governorship candidate in the state [coded separately].

On 4 February 2023, suspected Kalare Boys Gang members attacked the residence of a PDP chieftain at Gombe (Gombe, Gombe) where he had arranged a meeting with women and youths. Five persons were wounded and the house was vandalized before policemen intervened, the chieftain claimed that the attack was related to his defection from APC to PDP.

A policeman who was on duty at the governor's office was wounded by the rioters who moved to the Mokola-Dugbe axis and threw stones at people after they were dispersed by operation burst operatives.

actor1: JNIM: Group for Support of Islam and Muslims
notes: On 3 February 2023, presumed JNIM militants attacked the village of Dissankuy (Solenzo, Banwa). Five civilians were killed and several injured.

On 3 February 2023, an unidentified armed group shot and severely wounded a motorcyclist near Kobe (Gao, Gao). The incident stopped traffic and other road users present on the road stretch between Tacharane and Tianame awaited a FAMa mission to be escorted. Traffic resumed following the arrival of a FAMa and Wagner convoy.

On 3 February 2023, about forty people, including pro-junta civil society activists, demonstrated in front of the MINUSMA headquarters in the capital of Bamako (Bamako, Bamako). The demonstrators suspected that MINUSMA harbored a prominent female Fulani activist and demanded that they hand her over to judicial authorities. The activist has been threatened and subjected to a hate campaign after denouncing human rights violations by the Malian army and the Wagner Group at a UN Security Council Briefing on Mali.
On 3 February 2023, suspected armed Fulani pastoralists attacked and killed two civilians in Ikobi (Apa, Benue). Two other persons were missing.

On 3 February 2023, an unidentified armed group numbering five beat up a community bank CEO whom they abducted alongside two other persons at Nnobi (Idemili South, Anambra). The CEO was escaped from the abductors who fired shots at his car windshield and tires before taking him away.

source: Daily Post (Nigeria); Nigeria Punch; Premium Times (Nigeria)
notes: On 3 February 2023, an unidentified armed group clashed with policemen at a police station in Abagana (Njikoka, Anambra) and killed three operatives of the Anambra vigilante service who were on patrol before arriving at the police station. The policemen repelled the assailants who threw petrol bombs, destroyed some structures in the police station and set inmates free. Other sources report that two vigilante operatives were killed.

On 3 February 2023, a Katsina militia clashed with Yansakai militia from 11 villages who trailed them to a location at Yargoje forest (Kankara, Katsina) and attempted to recover cattle that were stolen by the Katsina militia [coded separately]. Some sources report that the clash lasted for over 48 hours; 41 Yansakai militiamen were killed; and later increased to between 72 and 102, two others were wounded, other sources report unspecified number of wounded persons. 72 fatalities split across two events coded as 36.
On 3 February 2023, Dan Na Ambassagou militiamen abducted two pastoralist men and seized livestock in Sama (Mopti, Mopti).
On 3 February 2023, an unidentified armed group killed two travelers along Iwuru-Turunkekpem (Biase, Cross River). An unspecified number of other travelers were abducted.

On 3 February 2023, a FAMa and Wagner patrol arrested thirteen men including a child from the Fulani community at the market in the village of Sagala. The arrested were subsequently summarily executed near the village of Doura (Segou, Segou). The decomposed bodies of the victims were discovered on 20 February.

actor1: JNIM: Group for Support of Islam and Muslims

On 2 February 2023, a Katsina militia ambushed a local defense militia that was pursuing them at Mji community in Kankara LGA (Katsina). The assailants received information about the local defense militia's movement from informants, residents claimed that at least 30 local militiamen were killed and several others were wounded. The police area command disputed the fatality figures.

On 2 February 2023, troops of 1 Division of the Nigerian army on a fighting patrol clashed with a Kaduna militia at Manini village (Chikun, Kaduna). 30 abductees were rescued by the troops who also recovered two motorcycles, casualties are unknown.

On 2 February 2023, soldiers beat up security officers on night duty at the main campus of the University of Benin at Ugbowo (Egor, Edo) after they scaled the perimeter fence to gain entrance. The attack was a reprisal following a clash between the soldiers and students earlier [coded separately]; scores of civilians including students were wounded and several vehicles on the campus were destroyed.

On 2 February 2023, a suspected unidentified cult militia clashed with operatives of the Anambra vigilante service who were on a routine patrol in Obosi (Idemili South, Anambra). The clash lasted for several minutes and one vigilante member was killed.

On 2 February 2023, an unidentified armed group killed a judge while he was presiding over a court sitting in Ejemekwuru (Oguta, Imo). The assailants who operated on motorcycles dragged the victim out of the court, shot him and left.

On 2 February 2023, students of University of Benin clashed with soldiers at the university's main campus in Ugbowo (Egor, Edo) following the students' resistance to soldiers' attempt to jump queue at an ATM and assault a student who they assumed was filming them. The soldiers returned later on the same day for a reprisal and attacked civilians [coded separately].

On 2 February 2023, large numbers of residents of Osun state and some members of the PDP protested in Abuja (Abuja Municipal, FCT) against the verdict that the Osun state election tribunal gave in favor of the APC candidate. The protesters claimed that the tribunal was unjust.

Security measures: On 2 February 2023, police and gendarmerie barricaded several roads of the capital and the Keur Gorgui district, where the political opponent and PASTEF party leader Ousmane Sonko lives, to avoid overflow in Dakar (Plateau, Dakar). Ousmane Sonko has been summoned to court to answer charges of defamation.

On 2 February 2023, an unidentified armed group invaded a police anti-cult unit and were engaged in an armed clash by policemen on duty at Obosi (Idemili South, Anambra). The assailants who threw petrol bombs into the police station were repelled, one policeman was killed, some were fatally wounded and the assailants' bombs destroyed some building in the station.

Property destruction: Around 2 February 2023, (between 26 January - 9 February), Nigerian troops discovered and destroyed 40 illegal refining sites and petroleum products worth over 128 million naira across the Niger Delta region, according to the Defense Headquarters. Location coded to Port Harcourt (Port Harcourt, Rivers).

On 2 February 2023, suspected armed Fulani pastoralists attacked and wounded a farmer on his farm near Oloke village in Ikobi (Apa, Benue). The victim was attacked with a machete and was asked by the assailants to inform the other residents of their coming.

notes: On 18 January 2023, a number of residents demonstrated to demand food supplies from the authorities in the town of Arbinda (Arbinda, Soum). Gendarmes intervened and fired tear gas to disperse the demonstrators.

On 18 January 2023, a mob attacked a man at Ekumfi Dunkwa near Mankessim (Ekumfi, Central) lynching him to death. The identity of the victim, his attackers and their motives are not known. Farmers found the victim's body next to broken sticks and rods. It is suspected that he was killed elsewhere.

On 18 January 2023, students' part of SUP at the University of Liberia protested in Monrovia (Monrovia, Greater Monrovia, Montserrado) against what they argue is the refusal from the administration to issue ID cards to allow freshmen students to enter the university.

On 18 January 2023, a mob of commercial bike riders set fire to a police station and checkpoint in Grand Bassa (Buchanan City, Commonwealth, Grand Bassa) to retaliate against the death of their colleague. He drowned in the river as he tried to flee from the police who tried to arrest him. The mob blamed the police for the incident. Police reinforcement calmed down the situation.

On 18 January 2023, FAMa and Wagner forces conducted an air-supported operation in the village of Sahona (Mopti, Mopti). Two people, including a merchant and child were killed by helicopter gunfire and another person was arrested.

On 18 January 2023, IS Sahel militants aboard 15 motorcycles attacked a vehicle carrying gold miners from the Dawsahak community near Agora (Gao, Gao), not far from the N'Tillit junction on the RN16 road. Three occupants were wounded.

On 18 January 2023, IS Sahel militants killed four people from the Dabakar community (Tuareg), abducted seven others, and seized livestock between In-Lamawane and Agazragane (Inekar. Menaka). The victims were accused of supporting GATIA, MSA-D, and JNIM.
Looting: On 18 January 2023, Dan Na Ambassagou militiamen of the Fato Camp branch seized about a hundred heads of livestock in the area of Djongue-Ouro (Djenne, Mopti).

On 18 January 2023, a number of residents lynched a robber and burned a vehicle in the Sosso Koira quarter in the city of Gao (Gao, Gao). A second robber was rescued and exfiltrated by police. The robbers had previously attempted to rob a gold shop.
On 18 January 2023, IPOB's military wing, the Eastern Security Network, attacked the Agwa Central Vigilante group in Agwa, Oguta (Oguta, Imo) and burned down their facilities. No fatality reported.

On 18 January 2023, the Nigerian Police repelled IPOB's attack on their station in Agwa, Oguta (Oguta, Imo). IPOB proceeded to the station after attacking the Agwa Central Vigilante group, coded separately. The police shot and killed three IPOB fighters. 3 fatalities reported.

assoc_actor_1: IMN: Islamic Movement In Nigeria; Muslim Group (Nigeria)
notes: On 18 January 2023, the Islamic Movement's members protested in front of the Federal High Court, Maitama (Abuja Municipal, FCT), over the continued withholding of travel passports of their leader and his wife. They displayed placards and banners asking for the release of their leaders' passports.

On 18 January 2023, the Nigerian troops clashed with the Katsina militia in Dangeza, coded to Batsari (Batsari, Katsina) and killed a militiaman. The troops recovered an AK 47 rifle mounted on a motorcycle with two magazines and one Baofeng HHR. 1 fatality reported.

On 18 January 2023, the Nigerian troops clashed with a militia from Kebbi state, during a clearance operation in Munhaye, Awala, Mairairai and Kabari villages in Danko- Wasagu, coded to Wasgu (Wasagu, Danko) and Maru LGA, coded separately. The troop destroyed four vehicles and eight motorcycles and recovered three AK 47 rifles, one SMG, 32 rounds of 7.62mm special ammunition, and other items. 7 militiamen were killed in the clash. 7 fatalities shared between the events, coded to 4.

On 18 January 2023, the Nigerian troops clashed with a militia from Zamfara state during a clearance operation in Munhaye, Awala, Mairairai and Kabari villages in Maru, coded to Maru (Maru, Zamfara) and Danko- Wasagu LGA, coded separately. The troop destroyed four vehicles and eight motorcycles and recovered three AK 47 rifles, one SMG, 32 rounds of 7.62mm special ammunition, and other items. 7 militiamen were killed in the clash. 7 fatalities shared between the events. 3 fatalities reported.

On 18 January 2023, the Nigeria Police shot and killed two members of an armed group along Ughelli/Patani expressway, coded to Ughelli (Ughelli North, Delta) and arrested another. The armed group had abducted a man before the police clashed with them. The police rescued the victim and recovered two locally made guns and three live cartridges. 2 fatalities reported.

On 18 January 2023, suspected herdsmen killed three persons and abducted 13 others in Emokpae, coded to Egbeta (Ovia North East, Edo). Some of the victims were women. Some children returning from school were also abducted. The abduction provoked a peaceful protest by the community, coded separately. 3 fatalities reported.

On 18 January 2023, two PDP factions clashed during a political rally organised by one of the factions in Ewu (Esan Central, Edo). One person was killed, and another got injured in the violence. 1 fatality reported.

On 17 January 2023, Catholic women and youths marched to demonstrate against the killing of a Reverend Father in Kafin Koro (Paikoro, Niger). The Reverend Father was burned alive inside his house by an armed group, coded separately. The demonstration turned violent when the police shot and killed one of the youths. The youths then set the Kaffin-Koro Divisional Police Headquarters ablaze. 1 fatality reported.

Around 17 January 2023 (week of), the Nigerian troops raided the Kaduna militia's camps in the Kutura-Rijana area, coded to Rijana (Kachia, Kaduna). The troops destroyed the camps and recovered three motorcycles and many sets of military uniforms after the militiamen had fled. No casualty reported.

On 17 January 2023, Nigerian troops clashed with Kaduna Militia along the Kaboresha-Rijana Forest-Kuzo-Kujeni-Gwanto-Kachia axis, coded to Kachia (Kachia, Kaduna). The army ambushed the militia in a clearance operation and killed two militiamen. Three motorcycles were recovered. 2 fatalities reported.

On 17 January 2023, the Nigerian troops of Operation Forest Sanity clashed with the Katsina Militia along Maidabino-Danmusa Road, coded to Dan Musa (Dan-Musa, Katsina). Two militiamen were shot and killed during the gunfights. 2 fatalities reported.

actor2: Boko Haram - Jamaatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawati wal-Jihad
notes: Around 17 January 2023 (as reported), the Nigerian Airforce conducted airstrikes and killed two wanted Boko Haram (JAS) commanders in Kurebe (Shiroro, Niger). The wanted commanders, Abu Ubaida and Mallam Yusuf Abba were killed with about 40 fighters in the air strike. 42 fatalities reported.

On 17 January 2023, hundreds of women and youths from the Nnadi Nsude community stormed the state capital, Awka (Awka South, Anambra), to protest the continued detention of one of their children. They alleged that their son was incarcerated on the order of a Senator since November 2022. They demanded his release.

actor1: Boko Haram - Jamaatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawati wal-Jihad
notes: On 17 January 2023, Boko Haram (JAS) shot and killed a farmer and abducted eight others in Makilwe village, coded to Khaddamari (Jere, Borno). The militiamen contacted the victims' families and asked for millions of naira as a ransom. 1 fatality reported.

On 17 January 2023, an unidentified armed group shot and killed an inspector of police while patrolling Iheorji Ohanku Road, Aba (Aba South, Abia). The police shot and killed two militiamen and others escaped with gun wounds. The militiamen carted away an AK-47 rifle belonging to the deceased officer. 3 fatalities reported.

On 17 January 2023, Katsina militia shot and killed three people in Jajar Kanwa village, coded to Jibia (Jibia, Katsina) and abducted six others, including a pregnant woman. The militiamen were armed with AK-47 rifles and arrived at the community at 2 am on motorcycles. They rustled domestic animals, stole money and handsets, and gave the villagers a seven-day ultimatum to contribute twenty thousand naira each. 3 fatalities reported.

On 17 January 2023, the Nigerian police shot and killed a trader at Alaba Rago Market, Alaba (Ojo, Lagos), when trying to arrest a suspect. Some traders prevented the police from arresting the suspect and threw different objects at them. In response, a police officer opened fire and killed one of them. 1 fatality reported.
On 17 January 2023, suspected IS Sahel militants killed a Malian cattle trader at his domicile in the town of Ayorou (Ayerou, Tillaberi).

On 17 January 2023, a Katsina militia abducted the APC ward chairman of Faskari ward from his residence in Faskari town (Faskari, Katsina). There are no reports about ransom demands.

On 17 January 2023, a large number of people demonstrated in the town of Tebaram (Tahoua, Tahoua). The demonstrators denounced banditry and militancy and a ban on selling fuel.

On 16 January 2023, heavy gunshots were heard in Foni Bintang Karani district, coded to Djifanga (Foni Bintang Karanai, Brikama) by unidentified armed groups. The initial fight is thought to be in Casamance but mortars and live bullet shots crossed the Gambian border and landed near villages. Casualties unknown.

He was taken to hospital for treatment.

Around 16 January 2023, a mob destroyed some Fulani homes in Mande, a suburb of Buipe (Gonja Central, Savannah) to object the enskinned Fulani as chief of Mande by the paramount chief of Buipe Traditional Area. 8 were arrested for the act.

On 16 January 2023, two sides of public transport drivers affiliated with CNTG fought in Siguiri (Siguiri-Centre, Siguiri, Kankan) over a misunderstanding on the management of money by the CNTG and the decision to renew offices. 6 people were injured.

Around 16 January 2023, a large crowd of youths gathered at the police station in Kiniero (Kiniero, Kouroussa, Kankan) to free their friend who had been arrested by the police. The crowd broke the door to the police station.

On 16 January 2023, Kaduna militia abducted eight persons including 6 women in Unguwar Alkasim village along Kaduna-Zaria in Igabi LGA, coded to Birnin Yero (Iagbi, Kaduna). The militiamen invaded the community and shot sporadically before abducting eleven people but released 3 of them later. They went away with six women and two men.

On 16 January 2023, an unidentified armed group abducted three persons in Kogi State, coded to Lokoja (Lokoja, Kogi). The three men took a ransom to the armed group to release two persons earlier abducted in Osun State. They released the first two hostages and held the ransom bearers. One of the ransom-bearers was released on Tuesday.

On 16 January 2023, the Nigerian Airforce conducted air strikes against Sokoto Militia in Rarah (Rabah, Sokoto). The air bombardment occurred in three different locations and led to the death of hundreds of the militiamen. 100 fatalities reported.

Around 16 January 2023 (week of), Sokoto militia attacked seventeen villages in Kware LGA, Rabah (Kware, Sokoto) and Rabah LGA, coded separately. Three persons were killed, and many domestic animals were rustled. 3 fatalities were shared within two events. 1 fatality reported.

Around 16 January 2023 (week of), Sokoto militia attacked seventeen villages in Rabah LGA, Rabah (Rabah, Sokoto) and Kware LGA, coded separately. Three persons were killed, and many domestic animals were rustled. 3 fatalities were shared within two events. 2 fatalities reported.

On 16 January 2023, people of the Ewherhe community lynched a man suspected of being an armed robber along the Ewherhe/Ovu road, coded to Agbarho (Ughelli North, Delta). The mas was caught with a locally made cut-to-size double barrel gun, one live cartridge, and some suspected stolen items. The police intervened and took the victim to the hospital, where he died. 1 fatality reported.

Around 15 January 2023, the anti-robbery squad of the Ghana Police Service shot and killed a suspected thief in Buduburam (Gomoa East, Central) after he refused to comply with police orders and tried to run away. The police also arrested another suspect.

On 15 January 2023, an unidentified armed group attacked a cow herder in Dongola, coded to Zeassou (Nzerekore, Lola, Gueassou). The attack is suspected of being linked to a long-standing conflict between herders and farmers. 1 herder was killed. 3 have been arrested.
On 15 January 2023, FAMa and Wagner forces conducted airstrikes in the forest of Nantinore (Djenne, Mopti). There were no casualties.

On 15 January 2023, soldiers attacked the village of Doukoro (Bankass, Mopti). Two persons, including an elderly man and a child from the Fulani community were killed, houses burned, and livestock seized.

Security measures: On 15 January 2023, the Niger State Government imposed a dusk-to-down curfew in the Lambata community, Lambata (Gurara, Niger). The curfew was imposed to restore peace and douse the tension arising from the killing of the District head by some communal militia, coded separately.

On 15 January 2023, an unidentified armed group shot and killed a policeman and injured another during an attack on the INEC office in Amechi Awkunanaw, Amechi (Enugu South, Enugu). The armed group razed the gatehouse of the office when they failed to access the building. 1 fatality reported.

On 15 January 2023, Zamfara Militia abducted four Tsafe College of Health Technology students along Kaura Namoda and Birnin Magaji roads, coded to Kaura Namoda (Kaura Namoda, Zamfara). The students were abducted when returning from their wedding ceremony.

On 15 January 2023, Nigeria security forces clashed with an unidentified armed group in Akokwa (Ideato North, Imo). The Nigeria military invaded the camp of the armed group and engaged them in gun fights. The clash resulted in the death of some of the armed group members and the arrest of others. Unknown casualties coded as 3.

Around 15 January 2023 (as reported), an unidentified armed group, numbering about twenty men, shot and killed a security guard as they attacked the INEC office in Oru (Ahiazu Mbaise, Imo). The armed group suspected to be Eastern Security Network (ESN), dressed in the ESN uniform, invaded the INEC office in search of the officers distributing the permanent cards. The assailants were heard shouting, 'No elections in Biafra Land.' 1 fatality reported.

On 15 January 2023, Katsina Communal Militia attacked a church (New Life for All) in Jan Tsauri, Gidan Haruna, Kankara LGA, coded to Kankara (Kankara, Katsina). The militiamen shot and injured the pastor and abducted five women from the church.

On 15 January 2023, Niger Communal Militia attacked a Reverend Father of Saint Peter and Paul Catholic Church in his house in Kafin Koro (Paikoro, Niger). The militiamen set the house on fire and burnt the Reverend Father alive when they couldn't access his house. A colleague of the father was shot in the shoulder when trying to escape from the scene. It was reported that the militia members divided themselves into two; a group went to the father's residence, and the other stood guard in town to prevent interference. 1 fatality reported.

Looting: On 15 January 2023, Sokoto Militia attacked Durbawa (Kware, Sokoto) and Bubari in Dange-Shuni LGA, coded separately. The armed group stormed the villages on motorcycles and shot sporadically. They rustled domestic animals and went away with other goods. No casualty was reported.

Looting: On 15 January 2023, Sokoto Militia attacked Bubari, coded to Dange (Dange-Shuni, Sokoto) and Durbawa in Kware LGA, coded separately. The armed group stormed the villages on motorcycles and shot sporadically. They rustled domestic animals and went away with other goods. No casualty was reported.

Property destruction: On 15 January 2023, an unidentified cult militia vandalized vehicles parked on Ehi and Akewukewe streets, Ijesha-Tedo (Surulere, Lagos). The militiamen searched for a drug dealer in the community but did not meet him at home. They then destroyed all cars on the streets in anger.

Another source claimed 11 of his gang members were killed in the clash. 11 fatalities reported.

On 10 January 2023, an unidentified armed group shot and killed a couple in Ndizuogu (also called Arondizuogu) (Ideato North, Imo). They were killed, alongside the groom's brother, while travelling for their traditional marriage. 3 fatalities reported.

source: New Telegraph; Nigeria Punch; The Cable (Nigeria)
notes: On 9 January 2023, the Yoruba Nation Agitators demonstrated at the Gani Fawehinmi Freedom Park in Ojota (Kosofe, Lagos), demanding the creation of Oduduwa Republic as a separate nation for the Yoruba Ethnic group. The police mobilised to disperse them and killed one of the demonstrators. The demonstrators reacted by setting the police vans ablaze. Another source claimed that the demonstrators had engaged with some members of the Oduduwa People Congress (OPC) before the police intervened and that the demonstrators shot and wounded two police officers.

Around 9 January 2023 (weekend of), an armed group suspected to be from the Aladja Community shot and killed two persons in Ogbe-Ijoh (Warri South, Delta). The attack occurred during the PDP political rally in the community and injured many people. Aladja and Ogbe-Ijoh have engaged in intercommunal crises for about a decade, and the attack risked escalating the tension between the two communities. 2 fatalities reported.

Around 9 January 2023 (as reported), the Nigerian troops and the police engaged in a firefight with the Katsina Communal Militia in the Magama area of Jibia LGA, coded to Jibia (Jibia, Katsina). The Nigerian military killed two militia members and recovered 2 AK47 rifles and three magazines loaded with 90 rounds of 7.62mm special and two mobile phones. 2 fatalities reported.

Around 9 January 2023 (as reported), the Nigerian troops raided a militia hideout behind Olam Farms along Kaduna highway in Chikun LGA, coded to Goni Gora (Chikun, Kaduna) and recovered 1 pump action rifle, 2 motorcycles, 4 mobile phones and the sum of One Hundred and Ten Thousand Naira (N110,000.00) after the criminal's fled. No reported casualty.

On 9 January 2023, an unidentified armed group attacked the Acting Rector of the Osun State College of Technology at Eti-Oni junction in Esa Oke (Obokun, Osun). The victim's vehicle was riddled with bullets but he escaped unhurt.

On 9 January 2023, some members of APC from Enugu State staged a protest at the party headquarters in Abuja (Abuja Municipal, FCT) over non-payment of $1.5 million 'convention allowances' by the party's leadership in the state. They accused the party leadership in Enugu state of misappropriating some funds and demanded the immediate removal of the state's party executives.

Around 9 January 2023 (weekend of), some placard-carrying youths protested the bad state of the Otukpo-Obi-Oju road in Obi LG, coded to Ito (Obi, Benue) and demanded immediate action by the government to fix the road.

Around 9 January 2023 (weekend of), residents of the Ipav community blocked the Yandev-Ugbema Federal Highway at Ipav (GBoko, Benue), demonstrating against the deplorable state of the road. They accused the federal Government of neglecting the strategic road to their livelihood.
Displacement: On 9 January 2023, residents in the village of Sanaba (Sanaba, Banwa) and surrounding localities left for Dedougou and Bobo-Dioulasso due to pressure from JNIM militants.
On 9 January 2023, Dan Na Ambassagou militiamen abducted and killed three Fulani men and seized three tricycles at the market in the village of Toroli (Koro, Mopti).

On 9 January 2023, a number of artisanal miners fought each other over the management of an artisanal gold mining site in the village of Sekou (Yanfolila, Sikasso). Two were wounded and a metal detector was damaged.

On 9 January 2023, some youths barricaded the road and set fire to brooms and APC flags in Jimeta, Yola (Yola-North, Adamawa), demonstrating against the arrival of the Nigeria President for the APC rally. The broom is the symbol of the All Progressives Congress in Nigeria.

On 9 January 2023, Katsina communal militia indiscriminately shot and injured an unspecified number of people in Sabon Garin Bilbis village, coded to Faskari (Faskari, Katsina). No casualty was reported.

On 9 January 2023, an unidentified armed group attacked and killed a 70-year-old man in Dan village, Dan (Alkaleri, Bauchi). The armed group invaded the community, shot the victim repeatedly and fled on sighting the police. 1 fatality reported.
On 9 January 2023, soldiers killed two IS Sahel militants in the area of Bakorat (Tillia, Tahoua).

The killing provoked a reprisal attack that burnt many Fulani settlements, coded separately. 1 fatality reported.

On 7 January 2023, an armed group suspected to be Fulani heardsmen attacked the Igueben Train Station in Igueben (Igueben, Edo) and abducted 31 passengers waiting to board a train. The assailants, armed with AK-47 rifles, invaded the train station, shot sporadically, and some passengers sustained bullet wounds before marching them into the bush. The police and the vigilante group later rescued five victims, including a retired police officer, a lady and three kids.

On 7 January 2023, the Nigerian Armed Forces conducted operations against Zamfara Communal Militia in Gado and Sunke (Anka, Zamfara) for two days, coded separately. The Armed forces killed 10 militias and recovered a cache of arms. 10 fatalities shared across the two events, 5 fatalities coded.

On 7 January 2023, the Nigeria Police shot and killed two unidentified armed group members along Gunimi- Anka road, coded to Anka (Anka, Zamfara). The armed men tried smuggling weapons from Taraba state to Zamfara when the police intercepted them. Assorted weapons were recovered, including live shells for rockets RPG, three explosive shells, 151-round ammunition for AK 47 rifles, and 200-round ammunition for anti-aircraft rifles and charms. 2 fatalities reported.

On 7 January 2023, an unidentified armed group attacked INEC PVC collection centres in Ikpoba Okha LG, coded to Idogbo (Ikpoba Okha, Edo) for the second day. Ward 01 at Iwogban/Uteh, Ward 05 at St. Saviour's School, Ward 07 at Ugbekun, Ward 06 at Maria Goretti College, RA 09 at Obanyator with Army Children's School and Ogheghe health centre were all affected.

The victim was part of a three-man armed gang that dispossessed the people of their valuables. The mob killed one of the robbers when he fell as they tried to escape with a snatched motorcycle. 1 fatality reported.

Campaign billboards of the APC presidential candidate and the party's Flags, the main door to the building and windows were also destroyed in the attack. APC in the state accused the Governor of the state of sponsoring political thugs against their members and facilities.

On 7 January 2023, the Icelander and Deebam cult groups clashed and killed two people at Mile 1, Diobu (Port Harcourt, Rivers). The Deeebam ambushed and killed the leader of the Icelanders and proceeded to a house where their second target was suspected of hiding. As they didn't meet their target at home, they set the house on fire leading to the death of an aged woman (coded separately). 2 fatalities shared across two events. 1 fatality reported.

The policeman had gone to inspect the accident, and the rioters were trying to prevent investigation; 520,000 naira was stolen from the tow truck that was set ablaze by the mob and the victims sustained varying degrees of injuries. Three of the rioters were arrested, the others fled.

On 1 January 2023, a mob attacked the convoy of the Sokoto state governor in Wamakko LGA (Sokoto), coded to Wamako, when he was returning from the PDP's gubernatorial rally. Two vehicles in the convoy were vandalized by the rioters who threw stones.

On 1 January 2023, policemen on patrol engaged a Zamfara militia in an armed clash along Gusau-Magami-Dansadau road (Gusau, Zamfara). One militia member was killed and the others fled, guns, ammunition and charms were recovered by the policemen.

On 1 January 2023, a Zamfara militia in large numbers abducted 15 civilians who were traveling along Magazu (Tsafe, Zamfara). The abductees were rescued after the militiamen abandoned them following a search and rescue operation by security operatives.

On 1 January 2023, a Zamfara militia in large numbers abducted a retired colonel, two of his children and two other persons near Yan Doton Daji (Tsafe, Zamfara). The abductors shot sporadically and scared people, there are no reports about ransom demands.
Looting: On 1 January 2023, an unidentified armed group aboard motorcycles intercepted a transport vehicle and stripped the passengers of their belongings near Agatarak (Ingall, Agadez).
Looting: On 1 January 2023, an unidentified armed group (believed to be Chadian) aboard about ten vehicles seized a vehicle and slaughtered a camel in Touaret (Arlit, Agadez).

actor1: JNIM: Group for Support of Islam and Muslims
notes: On 1 January 2023, presumed JNIM militants intercepted two timber trucks and a civilian vehicle about 9km from Tamou (Say, Tillaberi). The two timber trucks were burned and the occupants abducted.
On 1 January 2023, unidentified armed group abducted 3 women and 1 man from Koupouani, coded to Materi (Materi, Atacora). The circumstances of their abduction is unclear.

On 1 January 2023, Black Axe cult militia also known as Aiye and Eiye confraternity engaged in an armed clash at Shibiri, Igbede and Imude areas of Ajangbadi (Ojo, Lagos). The clash lasted from 28 Dec to 3 January [coded separately] and was sparked by the killing of an Aiye member by the Eiye group. Two other militia members were killed, split across 7 events and coded as 0.

On 1 January 2023, an unidentified armed group abducted a permanent secretary of Plateau state ministry of works from the entrance of his residence in Jos (Jos North, Plateau). The abductee was rescued by policemen in Bassa LGA after the abductors abandoned him and his vehicle.
